content:
Posted: January 12
												It came bundled with the Vive, so I paid for it.And this one is a hard one to judge, as its not really a bad game.Pros:+ on a technical side the game is fantastic, great physics and overall VR mechanics+ not only can you teleport, but reorientate your playspace, by rotating it while blinking, very intuitive+ graphics look nice+ one of the best inventory systems in a VR game today, you get out your backpack from your back and place it, to then put stuff in or take something out, very cool+ after the game was finished I kinda wanted moreCons:- its very very short, you will get through it in 1,5 hours- at the end of the game there is a puzzle that is insanely difficult and really needs a guide to be solved- the whole game is basically a demo for the Vive and VR mechanics, this is the stuff that should be free or at least very cheap- the price tagg is insane compared to the numerous better games that are out there and ultimatley made me decide to thumb it down. Its hard to believe that this 1,5 hour game not only costs a lot more than other very replayable games, but they are also going for an episodic system, which is downright greedy.- no replayablility whatsoeverI did like the games story and overall storytelling, but the greedy marketing is enough for me to thumb this one down.

												Honestly I looked at the reviews before buying it and I was really hesitant about getting this game. After buying it I regret not doing it sooner. content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I'm very torn on this review. Call of the Starseed was fun, the visual fidelity was high, the voice acting is good. The story is mysterious and makes we want to play the next episode. Playing leisurely, I finished the whole episode in 80 minutes. This seems short to me, even for an episodic game. This is also the second most expensive of the 15 VR games I've bought. On the other hand, this is the closest I've seen to a AAA game for the Vive (or at least the introductory chapter of one). As a story-based game, there isn't much (any) replayability, although VR in general is starving for more story and less arcade. Unfortunately, the VR market is still small which is likely the cause for the price if the devs hope to recoup the costs of their top-quality content. If the next episode comes at the same price, I hope they manage to significantly increase content quantity to match their already impressive quality.Performance is impressive, especially looking as good as it does. I have a GTX970 an an i54690K@4Ghz, and didn't have any performance issues after the beach, and the minor framerate dips on the beach weren't bad enough to cause the nausea that major stuttering does.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I was hesitant to pickup this game, based on some reviews, but decided to go for it, and give it a play through.  I want to support the devs, so I don't return it or something, like some others have done.  But with that said, I do agree with others in that, it's very-very short, for the price, and still has some issues.  The story itself was interesting, the audio was nice, and some of the interactions were cool.   But, I also ran into some bugs that broke immersion and also made me kinda motion sick.  The Good:- Intersting story- Nice Audio in general - The backpack storage is cool/better than traditional menus/ect.  - Some nice iteraions with objects/environment.  The Not So Good/Bugs:- Blink Navigation (Default Settings) felt a bit clunky to me.    Trying to rotate the teleport space was a little akward with the touch pad, but that's maybe a hardware/firmware issue.   Also aiming with your head is awkward/kinda uncomfortable.  I really like how Valve had it setup, where you aim with the controller, and press the touch pad to instantly teleport.  You have a delay in this game, as you "walk" to the teleport area or something.  - Some of the env. art felt a bit in-consistent.   The last env. felt pretty rough.  Geo wasn't too bad, but the textures looked almost placeholder/temp.  Lower res/too large of UV scale/noitceable seams/ect.   - In multiple cases, when I leaned my body left/right, the whole world seemed to move up and down or something. Which started to get me a little motion sick/unstable.  It wouldn't always move, and in some cases only 1-2".  But the worst was when it moved 6" to 1ft, and I really started to feel un-easy.  Not sure if a bug or what.  - When I loaded into an area once, maybe since I teleported into a doorway before the load, the loading icon/menu was broken, and I saw 3 large grey planes infront of me.  - In multiple cases, the Flare Gun ammo got stuck floating in the air attached to my gun.  Or I couldn't drop the ammo/interact anymore.  So I had to load it into the gun to get rid of it, or shoot my flare gun till empty, then reload.- The backpack, while cool, wouldn't get put away many times, when I thought it did.  So I started to walk away, and it was floating there yet.   Or I could try to drop items into it over my shoulder, and it would miss and fall to the ground.  Unless I wasn't doing something right.  - The game is very short.  Depending how fast you solve the puzzles.  But, even still maybe only 2-3 hours long.  - The env was very linear/not really much to explore or checkout.   I probably wouldn't play through a second time. Unless to show friends/ect.

Since looking around and playing with objects on the ground doesn't give me the satisfaction of a $30 title.  I can honestly say I didnt attempt to rush through this game before the refund period, there just isn't enough gameplay to keep me within the incredibly small world that has been presented.While the story is engaging, abiet extremely ambigous, it did give me goose bumps, but there was little interactivity when I did get to those points.  Simply pointing and pulling the trigger does not keep me entertained for the last 15 minutes of gameplay. I sadly can't recommend this title at a $30 price tag.However, if you enjoy having other people experience the vive for the first time, then this title ranks up there with The Lab in terms of quality with more of a focus on visuals and story experience.  This is quite simply a high quality demo of what can be accomplished on the vive when it comes to telling an interactive story.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												This one made me nauseous pretty quick. The problem is that the world raises/lowers based on the position of the headset. Since most of the ground is sloped, shifting your weight or leaning/etc causes the world to raise/lower. Also with the winding map, you're constantly having to turn around and reorient yourself after teleporting. There are a lot of objects close to your player, which isn't comfortable on a Vive. The 'sweet spot' for view distance on a Vive/Rift is at least a few feet from your character. I got this weird sensation after taking it off when physical objects that were close to me felt too close, since the Vive renders near objects as a few feet away. I also found myself impaled by objects several times while teleporting from room to room. That's a little awkward when you're already starting to feel sick.Overall, a high quality game but they need to apply some VR learnings to their level design. I'll try to work through the rest of this game in small chunks. Hopefully episode two has a little more flat ground..

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I was hesitant to pickup this game, based on some reviews, but decided to go for it, and give it a play through.  I want to support the devs, so I don't return it or something, like some others have done.  But with that said, I do agree with others in that, it's very-very short, for the price, and still has some issues.  The story itself was interesting, the audio was nice, and some of the interactions were cool.   But, I also ran into some bugs that broke immersion and also made me kinda motion sick.  The Good:- Intersting story- Nice Audio in general - The backpack storage is cool/better than traditional menus/ect.  - Some nice iteraions with objects/environment.  The Not So Good/Bugs:- Blink Navigation (Default Settings) felt a bit clunky to me.    Trying to rotate the teleport space was a little akward with the touch pad, but that's maybe a hardware/firmware issue.   Also aiming with your head is awkward/kinda uncomfortable.  I really like how Valve had it setup, where you aim with the controller, and press the touch pad to instantly teleport.  You have a delay in this game, as you "walk" to the teleport area or something.  - Some of the env. art felt a bit in-consistent.   The last env. felt pretty rough.  Geo wasn't too bad, but the textures looked almost placeholder/temp.  Lower res/too large of UV scale/noitceable seams/ect.   - In multiple cases, when I leaned my body left/right, the whole world seemed to move up and down or something. Which started to get me a little motion sick/unstable.  It wouldn't always move, and in some cases only 1-2".  But the worst was when it moved 6" to 1ft, and I really started to feel un-easy.  Not sure if a bug or what.  - When I loaded into an area once, maybe since I teleported into a doorway before the load, the loading icon/menu was broken, and I saw 3 large grey planes infront of me.  - In multiple cases, the Flare Gun ammo got stuck floating in the air attached to my gun.  Or I couldn't drop the ammo/interact anymore.  So I had to load it into the gun to get rid of it, or shoot my flare gun till empty, then reload.- The backpack, while cool, wouldn't get put away many times, when I thought it did.  So I started to walk away, and it was floating there yet.   Or I could try to drop items into it over my shoulder, and it would miss and fall to the ground.  Unless I wasn't doing something right.  - The game is very short.  Depending how fast you solve the puzzles.  But, even still maybe only 2-3 hours long.  - The env was very linear/not really much to explore or checkout.   I probably wouldn't play through a second time. Unless to show friends/ect.

												Expensive for under 3 hours of play! But one of the coolest experiences I think I have had with the Vive to date. content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												A very cool game that gives us a glimpse of the potential of modern VR for storytelling. It truthfully isn't much of a game, however. While there's a couple of puzzles and a little maze, it's mostly just exploring the environment, interacting with objects (which can be fun in itself) and discovering the story. The fact that, in VR, you are actually there, really makes this an experience rather than just a nice little story. Though limited, I also thought the voice acting was well done.That being said, I wish you could give a neutral rating on Steam, because at 2 hours, including a fair amount of time fooling around with breaking bottles and setting off fireworks, I think the price tag, currently at $30, is steep. I hope future episodes are either cheaper or include more content, otherwise I may not continue this adventure. And I do want to continue it. I don't know where you go at the end, but it's bound to be a cool trip. As a side note, I did occasionally have issues with skipping and occasionally a frozen camera for a second or two, but I'm also running an old CPU that caps out when I try to run Job Simulator and Budget Cuts, leaving those games off limits for me. Just as a note for others with older CPUs, it might be on the edge of what you can handle, but any hiccups I had were minor. I neither got nauseous nor fell on my face.  :-)

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Had some technical issues with this game, with the screen glitching uncontrollably at points. I noticed that it has a lot to do with optimization oddities with the Unity engine. But also... while well acted and I can see a lot of hard work going into it, I find myself desperately wanting. I would love to have been helping with a playtest in QA because I could have narrowed it down. Perhaps it's that actions didn't have much to offer in a fully physical game? Only certain objects are scripted... and buggily so. Why doesn't the log burn? Why doesn't the soda can burst? Why does the popcorn keep popping? It's nit-picky, I know, but it made me realize I was just supposed to bumble around and move on.And, while I am usually in love with explore-y puzzlers, I found myself annoyed that the first thing I encountered was "anti-physics" even if it dangled by a chain. Then I was supposed to see another, and I'd even say similiar looking, box and knock it down to advance the puzzle. All my continuity feels broke and I just ... stopped and, mainly because of the buggy refresh and tracking, I returned it. Sorry.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												I beat this several days ago, and I've been struggling to come up with a conclusion to what I played. On the one hand, it was lovingly crafted, with lots of little details and a great interface and UI. The time I spent with it was enjoyable, and it felt more like a tripple A game than most launch VR titles do... but on the other, it's so pathetically, laughably short for an adventure game it is insulting to those who pay good money for it. There isn't a whole lot here that isn't what you'd expect from an adventure game, but there's so LITTLE of it is what makes it a problem. The story barely, BARELY gets started. If this was a book it would have ended halfway through the prologue, it's that short! I don't know what else I can compare it to, but the length is just plain a joke. Is the story good? Who knows? There isn't even a ghost of enough of it here to be able to tell. Should we be excited for the next chapter? Who knows? This one is so short we barely got past the title before it was over.A serious player can beat this in well under an hour. The only reason I have as much playtime as I do on record is because I spent an unusually long time playing around with the environment... and despite the shortness, I managed to find a bug that wasted my time for over an hour by denying me a clue that was floating around that I needed to progress.I hate to harp on how short it is but I just can't get past it. To put it another way, fire up an episodic game from Telltale. Watch the intro. Now play for fifteen minutes. Stop, and that's about how much is here. Now look at what they are charging for this. Can this content possibly justify the price? Another way to put it, there are so few areas for screenshots, the store page actually has one from the tutorial room that has nothing whatsoever to do with the game, other than forced padding! That's some seriously bad form.Is this a cynical cash grab from a company that is exploiting the launch of VR by overcharging for a glorified demo because they know people will buy it due to the lack of titles at launch? I hope not, because I'd heard from the developer and thought they were more passionate about the project than that. More likely, it wasn't anywhere near completed, but the April 5th launch of the Vive was coming close, and they had to lock down what little they had completed and publish.I love the quality on display. I love the interface and gameplay, and I'd love to play a full-length adventure game using the systems developed here. It hurts me to have to bash something so polished, and I really, really want to give it a good review... But I cannot, and will not overlook the insane price being charged for a piece of game that is so short it is outpaced by demos on the old PC Gamer disks from the 90s.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												While the game is great, it is not worth the $20 price tag.I beat the game in just under an hour and a half, but there's no replay value to justify the price. I understand that this is only episode 1, I don't know if episode 2 comes for free if you purchased ep.1 (if that's the case then get the game).Now the price aside, the game is fun. Graphics are beautiful and life like. The UI is simple and actually pretty neat, probably the best inventory managment I've seen in a VR game. The story is interesting and gets REALLY crazy/cool/interesting at the end, so much that I eagerly look forward to episode 2. So you can be the judge, it's price vs. content for me. I'm giving it a thumbs up because it's an excellent example of what we can expect for first person narrative VR titles, but if you don't have a pile of cash you can blow away I highly suggest waiting for the game to go on sell and instead invest your $30 on a title that has a higher replay value.Pros:+ Great graphics for a VR title+ Easy UI+ Interesting story+ Awesome setting and enviromentCons:- Way too short- No replay value

Posted: March 10
												I had received this game for free with my Vive when I bought it 6 months ago, but was frustrated by some of the initial puzzles on the beach and put it away and hadn't played it since.I went back to it today, and boy am I glad I did.   The lighting and ambience are fantastic.    Being programmed in Unreal Engine, it's quite hard on the system - on 'high' settings with my GTX 1070 I had to turn off all supersampling to get rid of reprojection, but it ran great after that.   1.4x supersampling was playable with async reprojection on, so long as you don't mind a few jittery spots.

Posted: March 12
Product received for free
												I received this game for free as part of an special offer when purchasing my Vive. I also played a little bit with a friend of mine prior to purchasing my Vive and obtaining the game myself (like, I beat the first puzzle, that's it. x3)This is a good game, I'll definitely say that. The story is immersive and there are a few neat little puzzles you have to pursue. The controls feel natural and I didn't have any problems with the locomotion. However, the issue with it is that it's not a long game, by any stretch of the imagination. I finished this game in one session, from the moment I opened up to the game and the tutorial loaded, to the end of the credits sequence at the end, in less than an hour and a half. It'd probably take me just a little bit longer (say, 10 minutes) if I had never opened it up before. And I wasn't trying to rush through it or anything, either.It's definitely worth it if you're getting it as a sort of special offer (such as I did.) If, however, you don't have the option of receiving this game for free or anything of the sort, you're going to need to decide if an hour and a half's worth of immersive content is worth $20. It could definitely be considered worth the cost, and if you think it is, then by all means, snatch it up. Otherwise, I'd say wait until it goes on sale or something.When Episode 2 comes out, I'm gonna have to think long and hard to decide if it'd be worth paying for. I mean, I wouldn't imagine it'd be much longer than Episode 1, and I'm sure it's probably gonna be around the same price, but man, the end left me with a lot more questions than I had started with.

												This is like Myst or Riven for the VIVE.  It's a very well made game, immersive, great graphics, good voice acting, and the controls are well polished. Posted: August 6, 2016
												Absolutely recommended. While short, it's demonstrated the future of VR for me more than any other title by showing how stories and expressiveness can be harnessed by VR developers. Posted: August 5, 2016
												What a great experience! Finally able to live an adventure like we've seen in so many great movies and TV shows. The game is very immersive and is enjoyable from start to finish. Looking forward to future installments.

Posted: August 5, 2016
												This fell well below my expectations and I walked away disapointed. Despite having quite a few visual wows and a well realised inventory system I couldn't recommend it as I just didn't find it fulfilling.The first puzzle in particular is an unintuitive mess.  I spent about half an hour trying to work out a morse code puzzle that didn't exist . The sewer puzzle isn't really a puzzle  You can only go the wrong way by going to the well which lead me to think i would have to put items in the well to get stuff out of the sewer .Finally in the third and fourth sections the puzzles got more interesting. But after that it was time to sit back and enjoy the ride. In general the whole thing felt like the episode once had a lot more content which was cut but the hints of more interesting things were left in. There was never once a point where I got to use knowledge i had learned earlier. There was never a sense of mastery. So what was left was a game that felt like a theme park ride where you get shuffled from one scene to another.Unfortunately the story doesn't quite make up for the lackluster gameplay. [spoilter] The monolog near the end is painfully long whilst you literally do nothing for 10 minutes with very little happening on screen for most of it[/spoiler].In general its the gameplay that really needs a step up here. VR adds a 3D spectacle but this game could have been made without it and without it the game would be utterly forgettable.The controls are well realised and the rotating teleportation works well.  My hope for the developers going forward is now that they have the basics down they really need to double down the gameplay and puzzles for the next episodes.

Posted: August 4, 2016
												Definately one of my gaming highlights for the year so far.  A great experience which truly shows off the potential of the VR.  Simply amazing last chapter which left me gobsmacked. Cannot wait to contiunue the adventure in Chapter 2, although may delve back into chapter 1 to kill the craving for a while.  Not the longest game although an essential one.

Posted: June 7, 2016
												I seriously enjoyed this game so much. I have pretty much all of the VR games that are available right now and this one was probably the most immersive. It really makes you want to just stop and interact with everything you see. That being said, 30 bucks is just way too much to ask. Especially if this is going to be episodic. I mean, I'm thoroughly invested in the story but even with that I'm not likely to buy the second episode for anything more than 15 and I will still probably wait for a good sale. 30 dollars for an hour and a half of entertainment is just obscene. All that said, I will recommend the game, but be aware that you are going to feel like you blew a lot of money at the end. Especially since the ending basically hits you like a commercial break in the middle of a good movie.

Posted: June 12, 2016
												Wow ... I'm in for the next episode for sure.The 1st episode was short, but I don't regret buying or playing it at all. From the small touches of hearing the sea in a conk shell to the wow of the ending, it is the first taste of what a real VR game can be. I love the story and the sci fi part of it. The puzzles were difficult enough without being annoying. Effects are great even on my GTX 970 and I love how the inventory system is handled. It's a great touch to have the flashlight and toss around some glow sticks.To those interested, buy it and especially if you are on the higher end of the VR spec.To the Devs, keep up the good work and I look forward to episode 2.

Posted: June 11, 2016
												Kickstarter backer here. When the Kickstarter ran, I had no idea what to expect, but VR sounded cool and interaction with the Razor Hydra was a great idea.Well, now it's 2016, the Vive has been developed, announced, produced and shipped. The game was the perfect fit for the Vive's setup, even though it started development before all of that, and it shows. It's the perfect showpiece of what roomscale VR can do, it's the most immersive experience I've seen to date.As an old adventure games fan, this pushes all my buttons. It's (rather simple) puzzles, story, amazing scenes and exploration of dark caves. I felt like a child again, that discovered an old underground cave system and goes on exploration with a flashlight and a lot of imagination. Only this time, the fantastic stuff is real, and you are actually inside of it.

												Wow.  This was such a great experience in VR. Posted: May 31, 2016
												The only way to begin a review is to say that initially I was skeptical. I\'ve been enjoying the \"arcade\" style of most VR games as of late, and so I wasn\'t sure what to expect out of a narrative driven experience. Although it wasn\'t the most polished game, Call of the Starseed set the precedent for narrative driven VR games from here on out. Although deeply flawed in its \'blink\' locomotion mechanic, low graphical fidelity, and short length, the 15 straight minutes of shivers sent down my spine during the latter end of the game made every penny worth it. The only shame is that because it is more in-depth, I can\'t demo this efficiently to new VR players... Damn. I\'ll be replaying this very soon...

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Fantastic game.The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but cool nonetheless. I hope the following chapters do have some varying degree of difficulty though. The environment is a pretty compelling experience in VR, and very stable. I was able to play the last 90 minutes straight through with no issues at all. (Although there was one point in the first zone where you are standing on stairs, and if you move it's very disorienting).The game is about 4-5 hours long, but I very consciously took my time to take in all of the scenery. If you're turned off by the price, don't be. If you early adopted VR, shoot for quality not quantity. This was easily the most fantastic time I've had in VR to date, and cannot wait for the following chapters.

Posted: October 1, 2016
												In short, this is what an adventure game in VR should be.Great use of scale and lighting. The environments are pretty rich and interactive (including objects that don't serve real gameplay purpose), but this does mean that when you actually find an object you want to move and can't, it's disappointing. The story is just getting started so I don't know whether it'll be a selling point, but it's a good hook so far imo.The inventory and locomotion systems take just a short while to get used to and then are pretty good. Stowing items over your shoulder and retrieving them from the backpack handles the large inventory cleanly and is more immersive than a menu.I hope episode 2 is a bit longer and has trickier puzzles but this is a great introduction.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												$30 is a lot to spend on any game that will last on average about 2 hours. Still, I can't recommend this title enough.I've been a VR enthusiast for about two years; ever since I landed an early number DK2. In those two years I tried just about everything on the old Oculus Share and I've bought pretty much any title on Steam VR and Oculus home with a reasonable rating. In all that time, nothing has made my jaw hit the floor like The Gallery.If you have a Vive do yourself a favor and pick this title up ASAP. And please, don't give up if you get stuck on the beach puzzles. The parts of the game that really shine are the ones that come after you trudge through the sewer.Pros: Most breathtaking VR experience I've had. Period. Lots of effort put into making most objects interactive Very novel backpack inventory management systemCons: Very short (around 2 - 2.5 hours) A bit pricey for the duration As others have pointed out, the solutions to some puzzles are not exactly clear. There are hints scattered around, but the world is very detailed so they're easy to miss. It is extremely rare for me to me use any hint or guides but I did need to in order to complete the episode.Overall, I highly recommend this title for any Vive owner.

Posted: August 6, 2016
												This is like Myst or Riven for the VIVE.  It's a very well made game, immersive, great graphics, good voice acting, and the controls are well polished.  The puzzles were not always easy, but I was able to solve them all without cheating, so I'd say not too hard for an intelligent adult.  This is definitely one of my favorite games for the Vive!  I will definitely buy the next episode.  Although it's a bit expensive for ~3-4 hours gameplay, its a fair price considering how much better it is than other vive games.

Posted: August 5, 2016
												This fell well below my expectations and I walked away disapointed. Despite having quite a few visual wows and a well realised inventory system I couldn't recommend it as I just didn't find it fulfilling.The first puzzle in particular is an unintuitive mess.  I spent about half an hour trying to work out a morse code puzzle that didn't exist . The sewer puzzle isn't really a puzzle  You can only go the wrong way by going to the well which lead me to think i would have to put items in the well to get stuff out of the sewer .Finally in the third and fourth sections the puzzles got more interesting. But after that it was time to sit back and enjoy the ride. In general the whole thing felt like the episode once had a lot more content which was cut but the hints of more interesting things were left in. There was never once a point where I got to use knowledge i had learned earlier. There was never a sense of mastery. So what was left was a game that felt like a theme park ride where you get shuffled from one scene to another.Unfortunately the story doesn't quite make up for the lackluster gameplay. [spoilter] The monolog near the end is painfully long whilst you literally do nothing for 10 minutes with very little happening on screen for most of it[/spoiler].In general its the gameplay that really needs a step up here. VR adds a 3D spectacle but this game could have been made without it and without it the game would be utterly forgettable.The controls are well realised and the rotating teleportation works well.  My hope for the developers going forward is now that they have the basics down they really need to double down the gameplay and puzzles for the next episodes.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Fantastic game.The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but cool nonetheless. I hope the following chapters do have some varying degree of difficulty though. The environment is a pretty compelling experience in VR, and very stable. I was able to play the last 90 minutes straight through with no issues at all. (Although there was one point in the first zone where you are standing on stairs, and if you move it's very disorienting).The game is about 4-5 hours long, but I very consciously took my time to take in all of the scenery. If you're turned off by the price, don't be. If you early adopted VR, shoot for quality not quantity. This was easily the most fantastic time I've had in VR to date, and cannot wait for the following chapters.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												The biggest issue I had with this game was simply the fact that it was over fast and ended just as it was getting interesting. What it was is a step in the right direction for what we want exploration games to be in VR, and my critique of the game being too short should speak to the enjoyment I had of the game since it implies I wanted it to continue. Sadly it doesn't, and you are left feeling a bit shocked at how quickly you played through the game considering its asking price. As a game starseed is great, but sadly I don't think I'd recommend it (even at the as of writing this steam summer sale discounted price). If the price included upcomming episodes then I would have recommended it, but right now I'd probably recomend that you wait and see if you can pick it all up later in a bundle after more episodes are released - that way you'll get more value for your money and more content to enjoy at the same time. So for now this is a wait and buy later in my oppinion. PS. It hurts me to give this recommendation because the game itself is really fun and you can see the devs put a lot of love into it.Edit: With the change of the game being included in the purchase of the vive I am changing my recommendation. The game itself is great, the main concern was always the value/time which is now a non concern.Great game, great change and I'm eagerly awaiting the new chapter.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												This is easily the best VR experience out there right now IMO.  Really looking forward to episode 2!  Its a bit pricey for the length but its also an awesome experience.  If you have a powerful system with at least a 1080 i would turn the super sampling up as high as you can for this game as it makes reading the text in game MUCH easier.  For most people it will be located here: "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\config\steamvr.vrsettings" and change "renderTargetMultiplier" from 1 to 2.This game sold me on what VR will be once developers figure out how to do VR and once the mass market has VR to make the ROI worth it.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												This game is now included with the Vive upon purchase and for good reason, it is probably the single best showcase for VR, especially roomscale VR at the moment. The levels are immaculately designed. The devs treat you with intelligence by giving you sophisticated puzzles that enhance the experience. The puzzles are tied to the design of the game so they dont feel out of place. They require that you look for things which enhances the roomscale experience of walking around, yet arent overly simple that you solve them immediately. The ending of the game gave me chills, you really feel like you are sucked into a sci-fi movie, well done guys. As has been mentioned numerous times the game is pathetically short. I beat it in exactly 2 hours and I was really taking my time exploring and even struggled with the last puzzle. On that premise I could never recommend a $30 price tag, however this is the best demonstration of VR to date, so on that end I guess it's worth the $30 to see what VR has to truly offer. If you dont love this experience you probably wont ever really like VR.

Posted: June 13, 2016
												One of the better looking games for the HTC Vive, it has some beautiful environments and a lot of fun interaction. I love the movement and look of the hands, and the backpack system is awesome.The beach chapter is a fairly good experience to bring out for friends and newbies when you are showing them the VR for the first time. There's a fair amount of high quality content here for someone looking to complete the game though, especially if you take your time and look for all the hidden cassette tapes and listen to them. A few of the puzzles might be a bit difficult but just look at the steam forums to get some hints if you need them.If ever you wanted to be inside a Myst game, this does a fairly good approximation of one. Looking forward to the next chapter!

Posted: May 15, 2016
												This is a great chance to catch the game while it's on sale.Just finished this game, after having paid full price. Wow. Yes, it only took about 2 and a half hours to complete. But honestly, I don't get how people can complain about the length of this when the quality was so over the top, and just the fact that this is an entirely new genre!The last 5 or 10 minutes of this game were especially impressive.Looking forward to more!(PRICING RANT: It's not like they just took a normal 2D game, applied a little VR magic, and then upped the price for no reason. The entire design process is new, the interactions are new. Most games or VR products out so far offer 10 to 15 minutes of "gameplay" (i.e., just a VR movie) for 10 or 15 bucks. So at that rate this game would be priced at 120 to 160 dollars just for episode 1! But it's not, it's 30. This is a great investment in the future of VR gaming, if you're willing to take the leap.)

												Wow ... I'm in for the next episode for sure.The 1st episode was short, but I don't regret buying or playing it at all. Posted: June 11, 2016
												Kickstarter backer here. The game was the perfect fit for the Vive's setup, even though it started development before all of that, and it shows. Only this time, the fantastic stuff is real, and you are actually inside of it.

												Great adventure story so far! A quick tutorial with very little learning curve and your off. Good puzzles and mysteries to wrap your brain around. Contained some jittery bugs at points that have recently been worked out by the devs.  I hoped that it would be a bit longer, but I was satisfied with the experience as a whole and am greatly anticipating the next chapter. If you enjoy a good mystery story, give this one a go for sure.

Posted: May 21, 2016
												Having spent my childhood exploring point-and-click adventure games this was my go-to title when I got my HTC Vive. And boy, it delivered my first goosebumps VR experience. Although the adventure is somewhat short and not completely bug-free, it's overall a great experience with varying levels of difficulty on puzzles. Sceneries are rich, and there's a ton of non-required items to play around with to mix things up (which was fun for a VR-newbie). Without giving too much away the last minutes gave me the kind of dimensions I truly hoped VR would deliver. Can't wait for the next chapter in the series to come out.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												A brief but excellent glimpse into the type of interactive, visual story telling that is possible with VR. Just as the story starts ramping up the developers pluck you out of the game, leaving you yearning for more.My only gripe is the price. While there are other VR titles out there that aren't as polished as Starseed and cost just as much if not more, the fact is that there simply isn't enough content for the price.

												It's short and the puzzles are not challenging, but this is a singular VR experience. Posted: July 30, 2016
												Just Finished my First play through.  2.3 Hrs.  I took my time too.  Enjoyed the world ALOT.  So nice to see the detail in the game.  As with any consumer I would love more.  The story needs to be defined a little more.  It left to much open and didn't draw me in.  It feels like the show "Lost".  A lot of questions and not enough basic story.  But you have hooked me enough for the second chapter.  Also more puzzles would be fun.  Its mostly reading and walking around.  I feel that the $24 I payed was a little much for such a short game.  I know the market for VR games is going to be higher so to those on a budget maybe wait for a bundle when all the episodes are out.  Other than that its a fun game and would say go for it if you got the spare $$.  Def another fun VR RPG.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Fantastic game.The puzzles aren't terribly difficult, but cool nonetheless. I hope the following chapters do have some varying degree of difficulty though. The environment is a pretty compelling experience in VR, and very stable. I was able to play the last 90 minutes straight through with no issues at all. (Although there was one point in the first zone where you are standing on stairs, and if you move it's very disorienting).The game is about 4-5 hours long, but I very consciously took my time to take in all of the scenery. If you're turned off by the price, don't be. If you early adopted VR, shoot for quality not quantity. This was easily the most fantastic time I've had in VR to date, and cannot wait for the following chapters.

Posted: July 30, 2016
												$30 is a lot to spend on any game that will last on average about 2 hours. Still, I can't recommend this title enough.I've been a VR enthusiast for about two years; ever since I landed an early number DK2. In those two years I tried just about everything on the old Oculus Share and I've bought pretty much any title on Steam VR and Oculus home with a reasonable rating. In all that time, nothing has made my jaw hit the floor like The Gallery.If you have a Vive do yourself a favor and pick this title up ASAP. And please, don't give up if you get stuck on the beach puzzles. The parts of the game that really shine are the ones that come after you trudge through the sewer.Pros: Most breathtaking VR experience I've had. Period. Lots of effort put into making most objects interactive Very novel backpack inventory management systemCons: Very short (around 2 - 2.5 hours) A bit pricey for the duration As others have pointed out, the solutions to some puzzles are not exactly clear. There are hints scattered around, but the world is very detailed so they're easy to miss. It is extremely rare for me to me use any hint or guides but I did need to in order to complete the episode.Overall, I highly recommend this title for any Vive owner.

Posted: July 31, 2016
												Very pretty even with a 970, also I appreciate the lack of jump scares even though the setting kind of seems suitable for them. Controls and inventory system (backpack) are good, took some getting used to but that could be due to my lack of VR experience so far. Story was interesting and might evolve to something great with the following episodes. I did not like the blink-to-where-you-look locomotion, however you can change that back to point-and-blink so no issue there.The game took me less than 2 hours to finish with slow/moderate speed so people who optimize price per hour for a game might want to consider whether or not this is worth it. This is, however, a very good showcase of what kind of story driven games with clever controls and pretty sceneries we'll hopefully see more in the future.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												For a front runner of the virtual reality market I give this game a thumps up. It is an interest 'tech demo' that will have you enjoy the sights and sounds of being 'immersed' in a game world. However as a 'game' it isnt. Dont expect to be either having your wits or dexterity tested. This is a a point and click adventure without the puzzles. It is a story in a similair vein as Gone Home. Enjoy the ride, just dont press any buttons on the way through.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Fantastic intro, great story line, too short. This game seemed to end just when it was getting started. I don't know if is worth its price, but I thought it was great. The 2 things that really bothered me were: 1. The hands don't feel liek they are in the right position, and also they dont pivot around your wrist when you rotate the hand controllers, rather they pivot around the top ring of the controller. 2. The Characters mouthes never moved, and their animations were a disaster. These things really killed the immersion, as well as the hand issue. I think that the price will be justified for this game when all of the episodes come out, and they make a bundle deal. Honestly was a great experience, just ended too quickly for the price, and there were issues in game that I listed which weakened the immersion.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												The biggest issue I had with this game was simply the fact that it was over fast and ended just as it was getting interesting. What it was is a step in the right direction for what we want exploration games to be in VR, and my critique of the game being too short should speak to the enjoyment I had of the game since it implies I wanted it to continue. Sadly it doesn't, and you are left feeling a bit shocked at how quickly you played through the game considering its asking price. As a game starseed is great, but sadly I don't think I'd recommend it (even at the as of writing this steam summer sale discounted price). If the price included upcomming episodes then I would have recommended it, but right now I'd probably recomend that you wait and see if you can pick it all up later in a bundle after more episodes are released - that way you'll get more value for your money and more content to enjoy at the same time. So for now this is a wait and buy later in my oppinion. PS. It hurts me to give this recommendation because the game itself is really fun and you can see the devs put a lot of love into it.Edit: With the change of the game being included in the purchase of the vive I am changing my recommendation. The game itself is great, the main concern was always the value/time which is now a non concern.Great game, great change and I'm eagerly awaiting the new chapter.

												Wow. As far as puzzle games go, this one was pretty cool. Object interaction is good.Beware that if the ground is uneven and you turn, the camera has the tendency to move either up or down as it's trying to change your vertical position in the world (it seems). If it hadn't come for free with the Vive, I'd be pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I understand this stuff is hard to develop for, but come on! $20 per game, they say 4 episodes total...that'd be $80 for what amounts to a full game!Will I buy episode 2? Maybe...but episode 1 ending left me with more questions than I've had since Lost aired on NBC. Unfortunately these short games seem to be all the rage in VR right now, so hopefully in the future we'll start seeing things a bit more fleshed out as studios get more and more comfortable with the dev cycle. I'm recommending this because 1) It was free 2) the story is interesting 3) gameplay has a lot of promise

												The production quality of this game is good, and I really liked the music. That's about it. The game is short, there's barely any story, and only a handful of puzzles, only one of which actually took me some time to solve. The VR mechanics are basic environmental interaction.Not to mention this is just part one. If you want a good adventure game, this isnt it. If you want a cool VR experience, this also isn't it. I'm glad this came free with my Vive. Don't waste your money.

Posted: January 2
Product received for free
												The Gallery - Episode 1: Call of the Starseed really surprised me. I received a copy free with my Vive and neglected playing it for a while in favour of more well-known titles such as Audio Shield and Job Simulator. When I finally booted it up, I did not stop playing until the credits were rolling and I loved every minute of it. The mysterious narrative and gloomy setting of the first chapter was an instant hook and I remained engaged throughout the story. The game is predominently a puzzle-based adventure where atmosphere and story take centre stage. The puzzles were well thought out and challenging, though I felt that the '3Bs on the B' puzzle was a little too tricky to be the first challenge of the game. The soundtrack is outstanding and the high graphical fidelity really shows off the potential of the Vive hardware. I loved the ending and how quickly the game changed its tone as the mystery was revealed, however, the cliffhanger was painful and I hope the next episode is in the works and scheduled for release soon. My main criticism of the title would be the game's length. It took me just over 90 minutes to reach the credits, though considering the game's price tag this is understandable and to be expected. Overall a fantastic experience and I would recommend this to every Vive owner.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Magic. The only word to describe it, it reminds me of a more adult Disney movie. This is the definite real experience for VR, this debunks all the non-believers of VR saying they are just 'tech demos', this plays like a full game, looks like a full game and there is only more to come! I beated the game in about 2 hours, mainly because I sucked at the puzzles. I still had a ♥♥♥♥ing blast though, I can't wait for the second episode!Pros: + Great atmosphere/writing + Great voice acting + Geniuinly puzzling puzzles! + Great professional graphics + Story rich with great immersionCons: - Not really a fan of the episodic formula - The backpack system is a little faulty, you can't have two items from your backpack in each hand because you still need to put the backpack on your back.  - On the final part of the game, when you are moving down the elevator and twisting and turning in different directions to the starseed. It is REALLY nausiating, i had to cover my eyes because I was ready to throw up. This only lasted for a very short bit, however.REALLY good game for VR, 9/10

Posted: May 27, 2016
												I get some framedrops here and there with a AMD R9 390 on default settings (medium graphics), but apart from that, the game is absolutely incredible so far. And the story has that mysterious, supernatural, "something is out there" vibe known from games such as the old Myst or Atlantis. I'd absolutely play this if it was just a regular game, but the very well done VR implementation (backpack is genius!) makes this so much more intense. I have always been more interested in exploring new worlds rather than getting stuck on puzzles all the time, and so The Gallery EP1's pacing is just right.Recommended with full of love ♥

												★★★★★ 5/5TLDR;Can throw starfish.☺Pros- Can throw starfish.- Putting a conch shell up to your ear plays the sound of the ocean. Sweet one guys <3- The first storyline-oriented VR game i've played, and it's beautiful.- Scenery is of amazing quality and maps feel real.- Puzzle mechanics are fun, requires you to use your brain rather than faceplant the keyboard to complete the game.☹Cons- At times it was hard to figure out what to do, or where to go. (This can be put down to me, so not really a con)- Not enough starfish.I'll update this review regularly. :)For more VR game reviews and recommendations, check out my profile. :)

Posted: January 12
												I got this game for free with the Vive. It has some of the best graphics I've seen in VR, and some of the best, immersive narrative also. The only problem is that I didn't care much about the story, or get drawn into it until the end. I didn't even really know what was happening the entire time. It was still worth the play through, being as immersive and polished as it is compared to other VR games that are out.If I had somehow known how much enjoyment I'd of gotten out of this game, I think that $15 would be the most I would pay. For someone who really likes puzzles (light puzzling here) or is just super interested in this type of game then maybe $20 would be worth it to them.

												Up until I played this, I was not convinced that VR gaming was ready for more involved gaming adventures that you typically see in AAA titles.But this game has to be one of the most spine tingling and immersive things I've played... 												hey_that's_pretty_good.aviOnly really felt worth it because it came free with my VIVE. Not a fan of these "episodic" type games; $20 seems a little excessive for the 2 hours of gameplay (probably closer to half an hour of actual gameplay; I'm just a retard and had to break every object in sight, and at least 30 minutes of cutscenes.)A complaint I have would really be with the cutscenes, which felt awkwardly long and dragged-on. Seriously, did we have to watch every little detail of the machine powering up?That being said though, I was really excited to FINALLY see someone take a crack at a VR game with some actual plot which wasn't just some arcade thing, and this game definitely set the bar pretty high for any others.All in all I'd say it's definitely worth playing, but really only if it came bundled with your headset, or you've got obscene amounts of money (which we snobby VR headset owners do, mmmyeeeeess, quite so)

Posted: January 10
Product received for free
												I got this free with my Vive and so far the experience has been fantastic. Out of all the VR titles available at the moment, this is probably one of the best examples of a VR game and what can be done. From the start I was sucked in and immersed, walking around and just trying everything and being in awe of little things like using a torch ingame to find my way around or accessing your backpack. The standout for me was picking up a big sea shell on the beach and holding it to my ear and hearing the ocean, like you would with a real shell. It was the little things like this that blew me away. I feel like I'm in a classic adventure game instead of just doing a point and click around the screen. The only criticism is that I know this game is part of a series, and I am hesitant to spend £15 on each episode for what only amounts to about 2-4 hours of linear gameplay. For a lower price point I would say absolutely, but for £15 I think I would wait till a Steam sale or until you can buy all the episodes together. On that note, I can't wait to get home tonight to pick up where I left off

												A touch on the short side, but that's to be expected of episodic content. I felt the voice acting, animation, and environments were all well done (and made me a bit nostalgic for a vew VR rides I've tried at theme parks and arcades over the years. I'de definately recommend this game.

Posted: April 17, 2016
												The game is really well put together and is one of the most compelling experiences on the Vive so far.But I simply cannot recommend the game based on the amount of content in the game. It took me a fair amount of time to solve the couple of (actually very simple) puzzles that are there, the time taken mostly by not noticing visual clues which lead to the solution of the puzzle. But even with this relatively slow problem solving the whole game lasted 90mins. Its like a single level of a game.I fully understand the tiny market the developers are dealing with here and they would like to pay their own wages and invest in the future of the platform, but I have come away from this game feeling very impressed with the content that is there but unhappy with the amount of it.I feel like even within the small level that you play through the developers could have stretched out the content, maybe making it a little more difficult or simply putting more puzzles in each stage of the level.I think ultimately it comes down to this: Are you prepared to invest $30/£23 in not just your own experience but in the future of the platform and the developers, because you have to want both as the experience itself just isn't worth the asking price in terms of what we are used to as far as games go.I wouldn't have chosen a 'yes' or 'no' for the recommend option if I didn't have to as I think it hinges on the above question. Personally I think bringing the price down to £17-18 would make it easier to accept and help the game gain wider adoption ultimately resulting in not much loss of revenue, if any at all. Having said this I expect the developers have done more research into the market than my anecdotal guessing.Edit: Since writing this review the price has dropped down to £14.99. this is about what I would consider 'right' for this game, it remains one of the most polished experiences yet.
